summary:
The Security Council adopted Resolution 1730 (2006) on December 19, 2006, emphasizing the importance of targeted sanctions and ensuring fair procedures for listing and de-listing individuals and entities. The resolution establishes a de-listing procedure, which includes:

* The Secretary-General will establish a focal point within the Secretariat to receive de-listing requests.
* The focal point will receive requests, verify if they are new or repeated, and acknowledge receipt to the petitioner.
* The focal point will forward requests to the designating government(s) and the government(s) of citizenship and residence for their information and possible comments.
* Governments may recommend de-listing and forward their recommendations to the Chairman of the Sanctions Committee.
* If governments oppose de-listing, the focal point will inform the Committee and provide copies of the request.
* If no comments are received after a reasonable time (3 months), the focal point will notify the Committee and provide copies of the request, allowing any member to recommend de-listing.

The resolution requests the Secretary-General to establish the focal point and directs sanctions committees to revise their guidelines accordingly. The Council decides to remain seized of the matter.
Here is a clear and concise summary of the document:

1730 (2006)

7. The focal point shall convey all communications received from Member States to the Committee for its information.

8. The focal point shall inform the petitioner:
 
(a) Of the Sanctions Committee's decision to grant the de-listing petition; 
 
(b) That the Committee has completed consideration of the de-listing request and the petitioner remains on the list. 

If a petition is deemed rejected, the Chairman of the Committee shall inform the focal point accordingly.
